docs.lead_paragraph: TIME was of the essence to Michele Edwards and her three siblings during the winter of 1998. Her mother, May, who was then 86 and who suffers from memory loss, had broken her hip and had been moved out of her home in Greenwich, Conn., and into the rehabilitation wing of a local nursing home. But the move soon proved to be a mistake. Despite a good reputation, the nursing home had a rigid, unfeeling edge to it that, Mrs. Edwards said, manifested itself among other things in a strict bathroom policy: Assistance was allowed only at certain scheduled times. Yet when the family began to scramble for alternative living arrangements -- screening a dozen facilities for the elderly nationwide -- they ran into a new set of problems.

headline.main: The Many Life Styles of Senior Housing

docs.abstract: Assisted living facilities now account for three-quarters of new senior housing being built, and they offer wide range of services; many stand-alone assisted-living facilities are transforming themselves into co-called continuing-care communities that often combine, on campus-like setting, apartments for independent living, assisted-living facility, skilled-nursing beds and special-care facilities for residents with medical conditions requiring constant care; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Many States Slow to Use Children's Insurance Fund'' (front page, May 9) correctly points out that 10.7 million American children are uninsured. The problem is not that there is too much money for the Children's Health Insurance Program and too few children to enroll. The problem is letting parents know that the program exists. We know that 9 of 10 uninsured children live in families where at least one parent is working. These families are not accustomed to receiving assistance through government programs. Even if they know about the program, they may assume they are not eligible because they work.
docs.abstract: Children's Defense Fund president Marian Wright Edelman letter on May 9 article urges states to step up efforts to inform working families that their children may be eligibile for Children's Health Insurance Program

docs.lead_paragraph: Imagine what would happen if society could guarantee every poor person a path from poverty: an assured job at a sufficient wage, with child care and health care as well. How many would take it? How many would prosper? A decade ago, an unconventional band of reformers here set out to find the answer, and their discoveries offer an unsettling new look at the prospects of low-income families at a time of a national exodus from welfare.

headline.main: Project to Rescue Needy Stumbles Against the Persistence of Poverty

docs.abstract: Project New Hope, Milwaukee experiment in lifting people out of poverty by providing them guaranted job at sufficient wage, together with child and health care, suggests that inner-city poverty may be even harder to alleviate than is understood; has produced most comprehensive study of poor families of post-welfare age; recruited 677 low-income adults and made offer of jobs of 30 hours a week at guaranteed wage; only 27 percent stuck with jobs long enough to work way out of poverty and incomes were statistically no better than those in control group; project's clients showed no declines in depression and no growth in self-esteem, when compared with control group, despite conventional theory that going to work makes low-income adults feel better about themselves; photo (M)
